channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Gunmen in Paris Stage Deadly Attack on Offices of Satirical Newspaper
item.description: Initial reports said that as many as 11 people had been killed at the offices of Charlie Hebdo, which has been attacked in the past for satirizing Islam and the Prophet Muhammad.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Emergency services evacuating a wounded man from the offices of the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Eurozone Consumer Prices Fall for First Time Since 2009, Adding to Deflation Fears
item.description: Even before the recent collapse in oil prices, inflation had been falling amid slack spending by consumers and businesses that makes it difficult for companies to raise prices.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY and JACK EWING
item.media:description: Recent statements by Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, have heightened expectations that the central bank will announce aggressive measures when it meets in Frankfurt on Jan. 22.

item.title: Former Korean Air Executive Indicted Over ‘Nut Rage’ Incident
item.description: The executive, who was angry about the way she was served nuts, was charged with violating aviation safety regulations and conspiring to hush up the affair.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Tail of Missing AirAsia Plane Is Found, Indonesian Official Says
item.description: The development announced Wednesday could be significant because Flight 8501’s so-called black boxes were contained in the tail.
item.dc:creator: By TOM MCCAWLEY
item.media:description: A series of photos taken by divers working in the Java Sea showing what is believed to be wreckage of AirAsia Flight 8501. The images were released by Indonesia’s National Search and Rescue Agency on Wednesday.

item.title: Extremist Group Claims Responsibility for Suicide Attack in Istanbul
item.description: The Revolutionary People’s Liberation Party-Front identified a female bomber who killed herself and a police officer in a popular tourist area.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Car Bomb Kills Dozens of Applicants at Police Academy in Yemen
item.description: An Interior Ministry official said that at least 31 people were killed and that more than 70 were wounded in Sana, the capital.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Palestinian Gets 3 Life Sentences in Killing of Israeli Teenagers
item.description: A court imposed the maximum penalty on a man described as logistics commander in the abduction of Eyal Yifrach, Gilad Shaar and Naftali Fraenkel.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Hussam Qawasmeh, center, shook hands with his lawyer after his sentencing Tuesday.

item.title: Divers Spot Tail of AirAsia Plane That Crashed Into Java Sea
item.description: Divers and an unmanned underwater vehicle on Wednesday spotted the tail of the AirAsia plane that crashed into the Java Sea with 162 people on board, an important finding because the jet's black boxes are located in that part of the aircraft, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Paraguay: Officials Yield on Protest
item.description: The government agreed Tuesday to meet this month with former workers who have nailed themselves to crosses over a wage dispute.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: On the Open Road, Signs of a Changing Cuba
item.description: A road trip across the island revealed a slowly changing Cuba — beautiful, tired and looking ahead.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Julio César López checked his Fairlane.

item.title: Egyptian Leader Visits Coptic Christmas Eve Service
item.description: The state news media declared President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi the first Egyptian president to attend such a service.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MERNA THOMAS

item.title: World Briefing:: Russia: Navalny Defies Orders
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, said Tuesday that he had defied his house arrest by walking to his local store to buy milk.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea Has Made ‘Significant’ Advances in Nuclear Arms Program, South Says
item.description: According to a Defense Ministry white paper, North Korea appears to have made progress toward making a nuclear warhead small enough to fit onto a missile capable of reaching the West Coast.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Reports of Civilian Deaths Prompt Inquiry Into Strikes Against ISIS
item.description: The United States military has begun looking into two instances in which coalition airstrikes against the Sunni militancy known as the Islamic State may have inadvertently hit civilians.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Effort on Ebola Hurt W.H.O. Chief
item.description: Critics of Margaret Chan have said she lets governments around the world steer the W.H.O. to fit their own needs, instead of firmly taking the helm as the world’s doctor in chief.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Julien Gregorio for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Margaret Chan, a pediatrician from Hong Kong, was chosen to lead the W.H.O. in late 2006.

item.title: Leo Tindemans, 92, Dies; Belgian Prime Minister and Voice for European Unity
item.description: Mr. Tindemans saw European integration and a single currency as a means of overcoming the virulent nationalism of the past.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Leo Tindemans, far left, with other European leaders in 1974 in Paris. Beside him, from left, are Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, Gaston Thorn of Luxembourg, Harold Wilson of Britain, Aldo Moro of Italy, Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France, Cearbhall O' Dalaigh of Ireland and Joop den Uyl of the Netherlands.

item.title: With Veto Threat, Obama and Congress Head for Collision Over Keystone Pipeline
item.description: The White House on Tuesday made it clear that President Obama would veto a bill authorizing construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline, setting up a clash with Republicans just as they assume control of Congress.
item.dc:creator: By CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: A depot in Gascoyne, N.D., stores pipes for the planned Keystone XL oil pipeline. The House is expected to pass a bill authorizing construction on Friday, with the Senate taking it up next week.

item.title: World Briefing: Gambia: Leader Shuffles Cabinet
item.description: President Yahya Jammeh shuffled three major posts in his government, state television reported, a week after a coup attempt in the West African nation.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Anti-Immigration Movement in Germany Reignites Debate Over National Identity
item.description: The marches in Dresden have galvanized both proponents and opponents in Germany and raised anew a question the country has long grappled with: Who is German?
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Muslims gathered for prayers at a mosque in Dresden, Germany, on Monday. Protesters have been marching in Dresden on Mondays against what they see as the damaging impact of foreigners, and Muslims in particular, on the nation’s heritage.

item.title: World Briefing:: Belgium: Convict’s Request for Assisted Suicide Is Rejected
item.description: Doctors in Belgium have rejected a request by an imprisoned murderer and rapist for medically assisted suicide, officials said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
